cards.front: What is the Kronecker product \( A \otimes B \)?
cards.back:
For \( A \) (\( m \times n \)) and \( B \) (\( p \times q \)):

\( A \otimes B = \begin{bmatrix} a_{11}B & \cdots & a_{1n}B \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ a_{m1}B & \cdots & a_{mn}B \end{bmatrix} \)

Result is \( (mp) \times (nq) \). Each entry of \( A \) scales a copy of \( B \).

cards.front: What is the key property \( (A \otimes B)(C \otimes D) = ? \)
cards.back:
\( (A \otimes B)(C \otimes D) = (AC) \otimes (BD) \)

Kronecker products of products equal products of Kronecker products.

This is the "mixed-product property."

cards.front: How do eigenvalues of \( A \otimes B \) relate to those of \( A \) and \( B \)?
cards.back:
Eigenvalues of \( A \otimes B \) are all products \( \lambda_i \mu_j \).

If \( A\vec{v} = \lambda\vec{v} \) and \( B\vec{w} = \mu\vec{w} \), then:

\( (A \otimes B)(\vec{v} \otimes \vec{w}) = \lambda\mu (\vec{v} \otimes \vec{w}) \)

\( \text{vec}(X) \) stacks columns of matrix \( X \) into a single vector.

For \( X \) (\( m \times n \)): \( \text{vec}(X) \) has length \( mn \).

Key identity: \( \text{vec}(AXB) = (B^T \otimes A) \text{vec}(X) \)

cards.front: How does the Kronecker product relate to tensor products?
cards.back:
\( A \otimes B \) represents \( A \) acting on one factor and \( B \) on another in a tensor product space.

\( (A \otimes B)(\vec{v} \otimes \vec{w}) = (A\vec{v}) \otimes (B\vec{w}) \)

Matrix form of the abstract tensor product of linear maps.

cards.front: What is a tensor (in the array sense)?
cards.back:
A multi-dimensional array of numbers.

  • 0D tensor: scalar
  • 1D tensor: vector
  • 2D tensor: matrix
  • 3D tensor: "cube" of numbers (e.g., \( T_{ijk} \))

Order/rank = number of indices.

Rearranging a tensor into a matrix by choosing which indices become rows vs columns.

A 3D tensor \( T \in \mathbb{R}^{I \times J \times K} \) can be reshaped to:

  • \( T_{(1)} \in \mathbb{R}^{I \times JK} \) (mode-1 unfolding)
  • \( T_{(2)} \in \mathbb{R}^{J \times IK} \)
  • etc.

cards.front: What is the connection between multi-head attention and Kronecker structure?
cards.back:
Multi-head attention can be viewed as:

\( \text{Concat}(\text{head}_1, ..., \text{head}_h) W^O \)

The parallel heads create block structure.

Weight matrices often have approximate Kronecker or low-rank + Kronecker structure.

Approximating a matrix as \( A \approx \sum_i A_i \otimes B_i \).

If \( W \approx A \otimes B \), storage drops from \( mn \) to \( m_1 n_1 + m_2 n_2 \).

Used for parameter-efficient models and structured compression.

cards.front: Why are Kronecker products and tensors important for MI?
cards.back:
They help understand:

  • Multi-head attention structure
  • Parameter factorizations (LoRA has Kronecker flavor)
  • Reasoning about "position \( \times \) feature" interactions
  • Structured sparsity and weight sharing patterns
